title: Top Spiking Technical Analysis Articles This Week

text:
A resurgence of volatility hit equity markets this past week, following the stock market rebound from the previous week, as signs of severe economic distress continue to be revealed globally. As a result, market volatility has been producing wild price swings that have increasingly spooked investors. This volatile market environment has prevailed on and off for nearly three months as the global coronavirus pandemic continues to ravage economies.

While longer-term investors may have a strong aversion to the exaggerated market moves that have been the rule of late, shorter-term traders tend to prefer them. Larger price moves provide more potential opportunities for short-term profits (as well as for losses). In fact, we've seen trading volumes soar during the current economic crisis as experienced traders become even more active and new traders open brokerage accounts in droves.

For such shorter-term traders, technical analysis remains the overwhelmingly preferred trading strategy. Technical analysis is a comprehensive body of knowledge and set of tools meant to identify trading opportunities through the analysis of price movement, trading volume, chart patterns, and mathematical indicators.

Here at Investopedia, we've seen reader interest in technical analysis topics spike sharply throughout the past few weeks and months. Mostly, readers just kept to the basics of technical analysis—tools and methods that have been used widely for many decades and that are still favored by traders.

Here are some of the top spiking technical analysis articles this week:

A technical price pattern is a recognizable configuration of price movement that is identified using a series of trendlines and/or curves.

Here's one of those patterns—a flag continuation pattern—seen recently on the daily chart of Netflix Inc. (NFLX):

TradingView.

A cup and handle pattern on a price chart resembles a cup with a handle, where the cup is in the shape of a "u" and the handle has a slight downward drift. The cup and handle is considered a bullish signal.

Below is a recent intra-day example of a cup and handle pattern seen on a short-term chart of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY):

TradingView.

An exponential moving average (EMA) is a type of moving average (MA) that places a greater weight and significance on the most recent data points. This allows it to react more significantly to recent price changes than a simple moving average.

Here's a current daily chart of Apple Inc. (AAPL) with a 20-day exponential moving average. Notice how the EMA tends to outline the trend well:

TradingView.

Candlestick charts have become the chart type of choice for most traders. They originated in Japan over 100 years before the West developed bar charts. Traders use candlesticks to make trading decisions based on regularly occurring patterns that help forecast short-term price direction.

Here's a recent short-term chart of Facebook Inc. (FB) showing one of those patterns—a "Three Black Crows" reversal candlestick pattern:

TradingView.

The relative strength index (RSI) is a momentum indicator, or an oscillator, used in technical analysis that measures the magnitude of recent price changes to evaluate overbought or oversold conditions in the price of a stock or other asset.

Below is a current daily chart of Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN). Notice how the overbought and oversold turns on the RSI often coincide with price turns:

<div id="mntl-sc-page_1-0" class="comp article-body-content mntl-sc-page mntl-block" data-sc-sticky-offset="80" data-sc-ad-label-height="0" data-sc-ad-track-spacing="90" data-sc-min-track-height="250" data-sc-max-track-height="600" data-sc-breakpoint="40em" data-sc-load-immediate="2" data-sc-content-positions="[300, 1, 1, 1250, 1, 1]" data-bind-scroll-on-start="true">
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>A resurgence of <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/v/volatility.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">volatility</a> hit equity markets this past week, following the stock market rebound from the previous week, as signs of severe economic distress continue to be revealed globally. As a result, market volatility has been producing wild price swings that have increasingly spooked investors. This volatile market environment has prevailed on and off for nearly three months as the global coronavirus pandemic continues to ravage economies.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-1" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-2" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>While longer-term investors may have a strong aversion to the exaggerated market moves that have been the rule of late, shorter-term traders tend to prefer them. Larger price moves provide more potential opportunities for short-term profits (as well as for losses). In fact, we've seen trading volumes soar during the current economic crisis as experienced traders become even more active and new traders open brokerage accounts in droves.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-3" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-4" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>For such shorter-term traders, <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/technicalanalysis.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">technical analysis</a> remains the overwhelmingly preferred trading strategy. Technical analysis is a comprehensive body of knowledge and set of tools meant to identify trading opportunities through the analysis of price movement, <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/v/volume.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">trading volume</a>, <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/pattern.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="3">chart patterns</a>, and mathematical <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/technicalindicator.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="4">indicators</a>.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-5" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-6" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here at Investopedia, we've seen reader interest in technical analysis topics spike sharply throughout the past few weeks and months. Mostly, readers just kept to the basics of technical analysis—tools and methods that have been used widely for many decades and that are still favored by traders.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-7" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-8" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here are some of the top spiking technical analysis articles this week:</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-9" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-10" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-iframe mntl-sc-block-iframe mntl-block">
<iframe id="mntl-sc-block-iframe__uri_1-0" class="comp lazyload mntl-sc-block-iframe__uri mntl-block" data-src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/Z4WHC/1/" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="false" title="Technical Analysis Articles Spiking This Week"></iframe>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-11" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<a class="heading-toc" id="introduction-to-technical-analysis-price-patterns"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-12" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/technical/112601.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >Introduction to Technical Analysis Price Patterns</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-13" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>A technical <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/pattern.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">price pattern</a> is a recognizable configuration of price movement that is identified using a series of <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/trendline.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">trendlines</a> and/or curves.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-14" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-15" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here's one of those patterns—a <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/flag.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">flag</a> continuation pattern—seen recently on the daily chart of Netflix Inc. (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=NFLX" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">NFLX</a>):</p>
</div>

<a class="heading-toc" id="cup-and-handle"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-18" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/cupandhandle.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >Cup and Handle</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-19" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>A cup and handle pattern on a price chart resembles a cup with a handle, where the cup is in the shape of a "u" and the handle has a slight downward drift. The cup and handle is considered a bullish signal.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-20" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-21" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Below is a recent intra-day example of a cup and handle pattern seen on a short-term chart of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=SPY" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">SPY</a>):</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-22" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>

<a class="heading-toc" id="exponential-moving-average-ema"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-24" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/e/ema.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >Exponential Moving Average (EMA)</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-25" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>An exponential moving average (EMA) is a type of moving average (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/movingaverage.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">MA</a>) that places a greater weight and significance on the most recent data points. This allows it to react more significantly to recent price changes than a simple moving average.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-26" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-27" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here's a current daily chart of Apple Inc. (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=AAPL" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">AAPL</a>) with a 20-day exponential moving average. Notice how the EMA tends to outline the trend well:</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-28" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<figure id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-29" class="comp inline-image mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-image mntl-sc-block-image figure-landscape figure-high-res">

<a class="heading-toc" id="the-5-most-powerful-candlestick-patterns"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-30" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/active-trading/092315/5-most-powerful-candlestick-patterns.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >The 5 Most Powerful Candlestick Patterns</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-31" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Candlestick charts have become the chart type of choice for most traders. They originated in Japan over 100 years before the West developed bar charts. Traders use candlesticks to make trading decisions based on regularly occurring patterns that help forecast short-term price direction.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-32" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-33" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here's a recent short-term chart of Facebook Inc. (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=FB" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">FB</a>) showing one of those patterns—a "Three Black Crows" reversal candlestick pattern:</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-34" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<figure id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-35" class="comp inline-image mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-image mntl-sc-block-image figure-landscape figure-high-res">

<a class="heading-toc" id="relative-strength-index-rsi"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-36" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/rsi.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >Relative Strength Index (RSI)</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-37" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>The relative strength index (RSI) is a <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/investing/momentum-and-relative-strength-index/" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">momentum indicator</a>, or an <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/o/oscillator.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">oscillator</a>, used in technical analysis that measures the magnitude of recent price changes to evaluate overbought or oversold conditions in the price of a stock or other asset.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-38" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-39" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Below is a current daily chart of Amazon.com Inc. (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=AMZN" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">AMZN</a>). Notice how the overbought and oversold turns on the RSI often coincide with price turns:</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-40" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>

><span class="link__wrapper">Double Bottom</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-1" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">

<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-2" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">

<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-3" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
